CARDINAL . The provisions of LAW relevant to the present case are the following :
“ CARDINAL . The accused may instruct counsel at any stage of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . Where it is provided by law that the accused must be represented and the accused has not appointed or does not propose to appoint a person to defend him , the judge shall assign CARDINAL officially , preferably a member or trainee member of the Bar ; but the officially assigned representative shall cease to have authority to act if the accused instructs counsel of his own choosing . ... ”

“ The accused may revoke any act carried out on his behalf by the person defending him , provided that he expressly declares that intention before any decision has been taken in respect of the act in question . ”
“ CARDINAL . Where a representative is assigned officially , the accused shall be notified of the fact if he was not present at the material time .
CARDINAL . NORP The officially assigned representative may be excused from assisting the accused if he puts forward a ground that the court considers valid .
CARDINAL . The court may replace the officially assigned representative at any time on an application by the accused that contains a valid ground .
CARDINAL . NORP Until such time as he is replaced , an officially assigned representative shall continue to act in respect of subsequent steps in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . NORP The representative shall always be remunerated for his services ; the terms and the amount shall be determined by the court , within the limits laid down in a scale approved by ORG or , failing that , in the light of the fees normally paid for services of a similar nature and of equal importance .
Payment shall be the responsibility , as the case may be , of the accused , the assistente , the civil parties or ORG . ”
“ CARDINAL . To be valid , all steps in the proceedings , whether written or oral , must be made in NORP .
CARDINAL . Where a person who does not know or master the NORP language has to take part in proceedings , an appropriate interpreter shall be appointed free of charge ...
CARDINAL . An interpreter shall likewise be appointed if it proves necessary to translate a document in a foreign language which is not accompanied by a certified translation .

“ An accused , even if at liberty , may submit observations , pleadings or applications at any stage of the proceedings , even if they are not signed by his representative , provided that they relate to the subject matter of the proceedings or are intended to protect his fundamental rights . Such observations , pleadings or applications shall always be placed in the case file . ”
“ CARDINAL . The pleadings shall set forth in detail the grounds of appeal and end with submissions , set out point by point , in which the appellant summarises the reasons for his appeal .
CARDINAL . NORP If the reasons concern the law , the submissions shall also indicate the following , failing which the appeal shall be dismissed :
( a ) NORP the legal provisions that have been infringed ;
( b ) the way in which , in the appellant ’s opinion , the lower court interpreted or applied each provision and the way in which that provision should have been interpreted or applied ... ”

CARDINAL . Like LAW , LAW requires an appellant to complete his appeal with submissions . These must likewise indicate both the legal provisions infringed and the way in which , according to the appellant , they should have been interpreted or applied by the lower court . However , paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL provides :

“ Where there are no submissions , or where the submissions are incomplete , obscure or complex ... the reporting judge must ask the appellant to produce them , add to them , clarify them or summarise them , failing which the appeal shall not be heard ... ”

CARDINAL . Formerly , it was the established case - law of ORG that it was permissible to dismiss outright any appeals submitted in breach of the formal conditions laid down in LAW . In particular , it took the view that an appellant was not entitled to be asked to make good any deficiencies of his appeal , unlike the position provided for in LAW . That was justified by the particular requirements of speedy trial imposed by criminal procedure , the question of celerity being deemed not to be raised in the same terms in civil cases . It was therefore normal for ORG to dismiss appeals on points of law , for example , on account of the prolixity of the related pleadings , regard being had to the provision in LAW requiring an appellant to “ summarise ” the reasons for his appeal .

CARDINAL . In its judgment no . CARDINAL of DATE , published in ORG on DATE , ORG declared , with general binding force , that LAW was unconstitutional if interpreted so as to permit the outright dismissal of an appeal on points of law on account of the wordiness of the related pleading without the appellant being first asked to rectify his appeal . It emphasised that the particular requirements of speedy trial imposed by criminal procedure could not justify such a restriction of the right to due process .

CARDINAL . In its judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , published in ORG of DATE , ORG declared , with general binding force , that Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Legislative Decree no . CARDINAL , which are similar to LAW and applicable to summary offences , were unconstitutional if interpreted so as to permit the outright dismissal of an appeal on account of its being unaccompanied by submissions without the appellant being first asked to make such submissions . ORG referred to its case - law concerning the dismissal of appeals on points of law on account of the wordiness of the related pleading , observing that the same reasoning applied to the case under consideration , regard being had to the requirements of the principle of fair trial and the right to due process .
